The thing that struck me the most about this film is its brilliant script. Funnily enough, this is in direct contradiction to a lot of people's perceptions of the film; most find the script to be nonsensical and the characters one-dimensional, citing the suspense and the special effects as the film's strongest points.  While I will admit that the characters (or, indeed, the performances) aren't exactly the greatest I've ever seen in a film, it's the advancement, the mechanics and the allegory of the plot that do it for me.  I hate to echo or copy others, but zetes's 'freudian analysis' of this film (found in the user comments section of this site) was totally spot-on.  The bird attacks were symbolic representations of Mitch's mother's antipathy towards her son's love interests, and seen from this perspective the whole movie makes perfect sense, particularly the ending.Also great is the way the budding love affair between Melanie and Mitch is stripped of its childish veneer when they're faced with real danger. Their relationship never feels fake or contrived to me; even though they aren't the most realistic characters ever put to celluloid, it is clear that the movie is always to some extent a love story.  It's a far cry from the manufactured, crowd-pleasing "love-interest" aspects of today's thrillers, and added greatly to my enjoyment of the film.The technical aspects are all good, as can be expected from a Hitchcock film.  The special effects were no doubt marvelous for their time, and the lack of a score gives a realistic atmosphere that adds to the effect nicely (hundreds of birds shrieking incessantly will chip away at anyone's composure).  However, despite being well made, the film didn't have quite the massive effect on me that I thought it would.  Maybe it's my ILM-addled sensibilities talking, or maybe my expectations were just a bit too high going in.  In any case, such gripes notwithstanding one thing is for certain: by any standards, today's or yesterday's, this is good cinema. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Will the kids EVER stop singing?
reviews.content: Watch this suspenseful movie and you'll understand exactly what I mean.This movie actually had me edgy after I saw it.  It is one thing to watch birds attack and know why.  It is a whole other thing to watch birds attack and have absolutely no reason.The suspense of this movie makes it exceptional.I found a few things distracting.  The blonde (Melanie) didn't bring any bags with her to Bodega Bay yet for at least three (3) days, her hair was perfect, her makeup was perfect, and her same outfit looked perfect.  She was so perfect that she was distracting.  In fact, even the blondeness of her hair was distracting.Another distracting aspect was the likeness of the mother and Melanie.  I kept thinking they were played by the same person only age makeup was being used.Aside from the distracting aspects of the film, it is very good.

Film and lit experts say all the pages need to support the story. Well I realize how artificial that rule can make films if strictly followed. In real life, there are unrelated elements happening all around our main dramas. I find the awkward moments between Annie and Melanie to be interesting. I almost wish there were another film just about the adults with no birds no horror. As is, the adult drama as interesting as it promises to be seems to end up just "vamping" to use a piano performaning term before the birds come out to entertain. Here are some dumb ways to blend the two: If Melanie and Annie had disagreement over Mitch and Mel had to leave and got attacked. Or Mitch dashes out earlier to see how Annie is. Idk. Why spend all that time filming them discussing Mitch only to drop it. Make it all about bird attacks.

I think The Birds is a masterpiece , but I can't explain why. Instead I'll
offer a rejoinder to anyone complaining that it isn't realistic. I have
seen that complaint registered against "Top Hat" and "The Wizard of OZ"
too.The book "Slime - How algae created us, plague us, and just might save us"
by Ruth Kassinger offers this account:
The Santa Cruz Sentinel reported that on (August 18,1961) residents
Pleasure Point and Capitola wee awakened at 3 a.m. by the clattering and
thumping of a massive flock of seabirds-sooty shearwaters, to be precise,
with three-foot wingspans - diving into the roofs of their homes. The few
people who ventured out into their yards to investigate, armed with
flashlights, saw large birds littering the streets. Many were dead, but
some only stunned, and those, attracted by the flashlights, flew at the
townspeople. In the morning, residents found the streets covered in dead
shearwaters and "bits fo fish and fish skeletons over the streets and
lawns and housetops, leaving an overpowering fishy stench." Thirty years
later, a similar event occurred, only that time it was flocks of pelicans
with the bellies full of fish - that crashed into houses in the samecoastal towns.In both instances - and no doubt other that went unrecorded - the birds
were driven mad by a toxin they'd accumulated in their bodies. The fish
they'd eaten had scarfed up zooplankton that had in turn, swallowed a
certain species of micro algae, a diatom called Pseudo-nitzschia.

Hitchcock at his best. This film, has you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Although now 40 years old, it is still a film that everyone should see. Tippi Hedren puts in a superb performance. With an excellent supporting cast of Jessica Tandy (Driving Miss Daisy), Rod Taylor and Suzanne Pleshette.

The theme that is immediately recognized within the film is the mother and son relationship.  The mother in the film, Lydia Brenner is extremely overbearing and needy of her son, Mitch.  Lydia continually points to the fact that she needs Mitch in order to survive.  Lydia becomes especially angered as Melanie shows for dinner and Mitch show a true liking for her. In the scene after Lydia finds her friend's eyes poked out and dead from the birds attack Melanie comes in with tea.  During this scene Lydia makes it a point to explain to Melanie why she does not like her and it is strictly because Lydia does not want her son ever to leave her because she will be alone.  Lydia views Melanie as a threat, which is completely ridiculous! The theme is apparent again when Melanie encounters Annie Hayworth.  Annie is obviously still upset by her and Mitch's berak-up and reveals to Melanie the evil tendecies Lydia has. As Annie explains to Melanie that Lydia does not like anyone that is with Mitch, Melanie and the viewers get a cold and frightening feeling about Lydia and what her motives may be.  Overall, the birds attacking can connect to this overbearing mother Mrs.Brenner and her obsessive attachment to her son. The birds do begin attacking when Melanie arrives and the first person attacked is Melanie. As attacks continue Melanie is always present besides for one occasion. The attacks can be seen as an attack on anything that attacks Mitch. I think the attacks maybe a symbol of lose of control. Lydia maybe losing control of her relationship with her son Mitch because Melanie has entered his life. Therefore, it can be possible that the birds began attacking as Melanie arrived because she is the reason behind this idea of lose of control. Overall, I was pretty disappointed in the film. I thought the mother and son relationship was pretty interesting to watch and evaluate,but the film was extremely slow and lengthy. There was not enough suspense built up for the birds attacks and too much unnecessary dialogue. The special effects were pretty decent considering the time. The movie was too drawn out and did not have enough suspense and build up to hold interest for two hours!

i only watched this film because i had heard so much about it and it was being shown on ITV new years day. I found the film to be good for the time it was made, and it had an interesting story... but i haven't been able to stop thinking about it since i watched it! the birds just cant attack for no reason, so i came up with the following conclusions: 1) in the bird shop at the beginning, mitch says to Melanie that the birds shouldn't be kept in captivity.. (i cant remember the exact words) but it made me think about whether the birds were attacking because they didn't like the lovebirds being in the cage, and as they were all different species of birds attacking, i thought whether they were sticking together and therefore making the people in the film feel like they are in captivity themselves. 2) the birds only seem to attack when there is fire/smoke. when Melanie is at the school, she lights a cigarette, the birds come. when the lady in the café towards the end is playing with the match to light her cigarette, the birds appear, and in the final bit in the house, the light a fire and Melanie gets attacked. i am sure i will think of more, but please do post and tell me what you think of my theories!

The major problem is that there is no real end, so we don't really no why birds attacked. It is a great film but there is no point in watching it because its main issue isn't solved at the end, Hitchcock lets us with no answer, it is so disappointing. Even if the film ends too early as if it was cut, the plot is really original and passionate. The actors are well chosen, Mitch (Rod Taylor) is the man for the job. Althrough the film we can feel a tense atmosphere, particularly when Melanie (Tippi Hedren) climbs the stairs to look into the bedroom. The story is very absorbing, but the movie is too short ! Hitchcock is really the master of suspense ! He was very talented for his time ! A movie to see if you love no end movies.

One of Hitchcock's most popular movies, "The Birds" proves his reputation as "The Master of Suspense." There are many suspenseful and scary moments. You see the gas pooling around the vehicle as the idiot lights his cigarette at the pump. You see the birds gathering menacingly to...do what? Hitchcock's timing is perfect as the scene resolves as you knew it would.My favorite character is the ornithologist (amateur, I presume) lady at the gas station. She is so sure that birds would never behave in the manner described that you are almost eager for them to prove her wrong!I have seen the movie several times and enjoyed it very much. But it doesn't make my list of top Hitchcock films because it is more predictable than many others. And I found the ending dissatisfying.Want great characters and plot development? See "Vertigo" or "Rear Window."Plot twists? "The Man Who Knew Too Much" or "Psycho."Want a big surprise at the end? Try "North by Northwest."A superb adaptation of a Daphne duMaurier story? "Rebecca."Great acting? Any of the above, or "Strangers on a Train."An entertaining evening watching a relatively easy-to-follow plot by one of the greatest directors ever, while munching on your popcorn? Now you can see "The Birds."

reviews.review_title: Not as suspenseful as I imagined
reviews.content: This film is okay. Not very special like Hitchcock's "Psycho" but not as bad as many other modern horror-films. The effects with the birds are pretty good but I don't really think that birds can scare you as much as a shark can do, like in Spielberg's "Jaws" for example, which was much better I think. If Hitchcock would have done a movie like this with other animals it would have been better! I rate it 6 out to 10.

I saw this movie last night during a midnight screening at the student theater. After all the wonderful things I had heard about it (Hitchcock's best!), I was extremely disappointed. This movie did not age well at all.The story involves a capricious woman who apparently has played practical jokes following a man to Bodega Bay to deliver some lovebirds. We are not completely sure as to how or why they know each other, but we do know that there is a mutual attraction. Due to some strange attacks by birds, she stays with the man, the young sister, and the elderly, bizarre mother. The attacks become progressively worse, and we watch how they cope with it.Not only are the special effects horrible, the acting was a completely different style as well. Many times the camera would focus on a character doing their best to put on an "intense" face. Throughout the movie, the whole audience was laughing almost hysterically. I can't recall a time when I laughed more in a movie theater. Not to mention the awkward laughter that came after the movie ended when people thought the reel had broken, or something along that line to explain the odd ending.Obviously there were some elements that illustrate why some regard it as excellent. The fact that Hitchcock could create suspense with no score is mind-blowing. I am a huge Hitchcock fan, but I don't know if I would ever recommend this.Bottom line - this movie does not translate well.

Incredibly scary late Hitchcock with many effective moments (especially the attack in the bedroom and at the children's party).  Excellent performances from Taylor, Hedron and Tandy prevail, but the film is flawed by a weak plot (Hedren coming all the way from San Francisco) and the film lacks a proper ending.  The murkyness surrounding the possible connection between the attacks and the lovebirds is very smart, and the film is a Hitchcock worth seeing.

Hello fellow movie buffs!After repeated urgings from my brother, I relented and rented "The Birds". What a stinker! The only thing missing was Jessica Fletcher. I tried to allow for the fact that SFX technology was not quite as advanced back in 1963 but that didn't work for me. It's still awful. Wooden performances and a lousy production. Ugh!Just my opinion, of course.

No music - an original touch (as far I as I know).A bit dated, but so what? Tipi was a little much with the furs and heels and all in a resort town. And the ending could have been stronger if they had gone with the original idea of having the birds shown massed on the Golden Gate bridge in SF to show the extent of the horror. Those are my negatives, but otherwise the film was scary and vintage Hitch, always with the "master's touch". His humor is often not far below the surface.The screenplay is superior to DeMaurier's short story in that it broadened the scope a bit and brought real people into the mix. The special effects were spectacular and the acting convincing. The town of Bodega Bay as presented by Hitchcock was in perfect bucolic juxtaposition to the terrifying concept of nature gone wrong. I've seen this film many times and could watch it again and again. I can't say that about too many movies. Recommended!

reviews.review_title: The Birds vs The birds as written by author.
reviews.content: Nothing like the book. Yet Hitchcock was suppose to be a fan.The book does not need altering for dramatic effect, true is is written by an English Lady and set in England, but it could be set in the USA as still keep true.Both end with no conclusion, but in the book it is a wide spread attack, possibly the whole world, making the danger far greater than the film, where most attacks are only at that bay. Of course there is no glamorous blonde in the book, but instead centers around a married man trying to keep his wife and children safe. The film is set in summer, where as the book in winter, Hitchcock also added an attractive school teacher and townsfolk, all not in the book.So you lose the isolation of the farm where the family live. I first saw The Birds over thirty years ago, and I remember being underwhelmed by the experience. As I am not a lover of horror films per sae, I just thought it was a good film but not for me. However, I recently had a chance to watch it again and found my real niggle was much more apperant,

But here we have Melodie Daniels, and she just comes across as a cold and spoilt socialite. I just did not like her. In fact, I felt more in tune with Annie, the school teacher who dies. In my humble opinion, it could have been a better film if that character was the lead.

Alfred Hitchcock's nightmarish tale about the avian-world inflicting a terrible vengeance on their human tormentors.Rod Taylor stars as Mitch Brenner, a bachelor lawyer. The story begins with Brenner having a fractious encounter in a San Francisco pet shop with Melanie Daniels, a chic but haughty young woman, played by Tippi Hedren, Hitchcock's latest hunk of blonde ice. Clearly smitten by the handsome attorney, the woman follows him to his home in Bodega Bay, an idyllic fishing hamlet north of the city to give him a peace offering of two love birds. However, her arrival with the captive livestock in tow seems to trigger a hostile reaction from the local feathered population. Beginning with an odd, momentary assault on the mysterious visitor by a lone seagull, all hell eventually breaks loose when thousands of marauding birds of different species repeatedly attack the small community. Jessica Tandy is Taylor's clinging and domineering mother with Veronica Cartwright as his sister and Suzanne Pleshette as his ex- girlfriend. Taylor, in his prime, looks good and makes a powerful and comforting protector in life-threatening circumstances.Although the pedestrian script by Evan Hunter (based on a short story by Daphne Du Maurier) doesn't provide any real scope for the cast, the performances are still excellent. And, in the end, Hitchcock's sheer mastery of suspense over rides any shortcomings. "The Birds" premiered in March, 1963 to somewhat mixed reviews. The public, however, showed no such ambivalence and (dare I say it ?), 'flocked' to cinemas across America to partake in the quirky horror that was on offer. Obviously, it's an effects - driven movie and on that count it still packs a punch.

reviews.review_title: Don't bother if you value your sanity
reviews.content: Alfred Hitchcock: depending on you, you will either love him or hate him with all your guts. If you like barf-causing horror and suspense to render your limbs into jelly, as well as a un-foreseeable twist, then this is your movie. It is appreciatable, no matter what. But if you are a person who appreciates movies that make you roar with laughter and recall it the next night with a smile, you will HATE this movie. It will render you to a trembling mass of nerves, and leave you fuming with outrage at the end. If you appreciate suspense, mystery, twists and a movie that will keep your eyes glued to the screen, you could not find a movie to beat The Birds. Otherwise, leave it well alone.

This movie was great and enjoyable,because the movie maker, Hithcock himself, produces an amazing suspense which will amaze you. The plot is based on a pathetic love story which involves Mitch and Melanie. Some stereotypes are very visible for instance : Melanie is weak, and Mitch is a kind of hero in this movie, he is indeed The Husband. However, an attack of birds is creative and original compared to the other typical horror movies, which is a good point. The story is a bit boring, and it ends up going nowhere, especiallly considering that the end is very disappointing.We advise you to Watch this movie if you enjoy suspense and old-fashionned movies!

reviews.review_title: A Good Movie, but not the Best of Hitchcock!
reviews.content:
This is really a good movie.
Of course this is not one of Hitchcock's greatest works like Rebecca (1940), Vertigo (1958) or Psycho (1960), but there are great scenes of attack, suspense and the dialogues are very good. However the film does not provide important clarifications on the reason for the attacks and the end seemed very lazy and sloppy.Still, it's worth checking out!

reviews.review_title: Ending left viewers a bit disappointed.
reviews.content: Sure, this was a fun and somewhat surprisingly violent film but I was expecting a classic Hitchcock twist.There was no twist.They drove off.Into the unknown.

reviews.review_title: slightly overrated Hitchcock...shocking,but dull and superficial...
reviews.content: i bought this movie while i was passing through a "hitchcockian" phase.it all started by buying vertigo after reading all the good reviews,and i really liked it.then my second pick was psycho which i already saw on TV,but really watching it on DVD was different,i loved it.then i bought the birds,supposedly another masterpiece...i was slightly disappointed,the characters are underdeveloped,the storyline is one-dimensional,the whole concept of the movie is more like a documentary than a real movie(especially a Hitchcock movie). ...........but,the birds really is a shocking and strange film and it has it's share of hitchcockian black humor.i guess if u deal with the fact that this movie has no musical score,no plot,no character development and no real human emotion,then...u may love it.but if u want real Hitchcock,try "vertigo","psycho","rear window" and the less notorious but perfect "notorious".

The Birds, directed by Alfred Hitchcock, is a really strange movie. It has a complicated plot which can sometimes drive you crazy. However, the storyline is quite interesting and original, for the time. It takes a while to get into the story, it would be better if the issue that the characters have to face came earlier, because it is really long, and boring. The acting sometimes was a bit overacted. The main actress, Tippi Hedren, is really pretty and plays well, and Rod Taylor is also a good actor. The mother's character, played by Jessica Tandy, can seem annoying because she is overprotective with her son, not being nice to whoever he brings home. The movie fits the society of that time, like the fact that there is no father in the family, or their way of life which is normal. The special effects can seem ridiculous, but for 1963 it has an amazing quality. It was realistic at that time. However, the end is realistic but the suspense goes on and on, and it doesn't have a real end. It seems like the movie was just cut off because there isn't an outcome. The suspense is good and you want to discover more, but since there's no ending, you don't know the end of the story and it's frustrating.

I just saw Alfred Hitchcocks's "The Birds" last night and it surprised me. For a movie about birds attacking a small California town, it was very suspenseful. Hitchcock handled the scenes very well, and the script was well written. I have to say though that the special effects were rather cheap, but I am sure back in 1963 they were state of the art. I thought that the scene where all of the birds attack the Brenners and Ms. Daniels was very creepy. However, I found that the ending was considerably disappointing, but other than that I cannot complain at all. It isn't up to todays standards of horror, but i found it quite enjoyable, so if you're looking for a good thriller, "The Birds" is definitely worth a look.

Although I love Alfred Hitchcock's movies I think that birds is an overrated movie. Sure the actors are great the scenery is beautiful and overall it is a very well-made film but I think there are plot holes. For instance I believe that it should have been explained why the birds attacted people or give at least some details on that because it was the main story. To sum up I think that the film is based on good actors and great director but they forgot about the plot.

Classic Hitchcock.
He is the God Father of film & story telling.

Oh man Alfred Hitchcock what was this? I heard this movie was critically acclaimed and loved by a majority of the audience so I decided that I was going to watch this. At the end of the day, a plot about birds attacking humans is a pretty ridiculous plot. The birds barely feel like a threat throughout the movie and the characters feel like the are overreacting. There's literally talk about the world ending. Over bird?! Are you kidding me?! It was just too ridiculous for me to fully immerse myself into the story. Also the characters are bland at best. I have no reason to like them at all. On top of all that, there's a corny love story that takes up a majority of the first half of the movie. It's just so ridiculous. One of the only things that save this movie are the dialogue and the acting. Both of those things are well-done and you can see the excellence of Alfred Hitchcock's directing shine through. Overall, this was just not a good movie in my opinion and I'm very disappointed.
This is a classic?… it was so bad!… I'm never watching this again.
All time classic. No green screens. All real including the birds

It's an excellent motion picture, The Birds, 1963, by my favourite director-producer, Alfred Hitchcock...

A debut actress, Nathalie Kay "Tippi" Hedren is my second time on her movie...

I don't know why people like this film so much. The exposition of the characters and their drama in the first half of the film seems so pointless, since they don't matter in any way to the overall story. I spend maybe half the time of the film wandering where are the birds, since it's called "The Birds". The screenplay is very bad because it is so obviously an adaptation of a book. Like for example there are moments that may work for a reader, but definitely don't work for a viewer. A perfect example of this is the dialogue scene in the bar, where it seems everybody has something to say and it looks so fake and staged. Which brings me to the acting, and some of the actors are very bad at it, while the others are decent at best. While it's so hard to criticize the visual effects of "the birds", since the film was made so long ago, I still think that they could have put more effort into it to look at least remotely realistic and entertaining. The biggest suspense I experienced in this film was the anticipation of waiting for it to end.

The Birds is a 1963 cinematic triumph. This is visual content giving ultimate force to birds and their attacks. It achieves its goal of horrifying and shocking. Nothing else matters but the amazing control of birds real and mechanical giving audiences an unforgettable experience. Birds are and always have been omens and symbols of something like death approaching. It doesn't matter why the birds are attacking just that they are. The brilliance here is watching how Hitchcock is able to bring a romantic encounter with love birds to such horrifying heights.

I can't understand why this movie was such a commercial and critical success: regarded as a classic even.  Birds just aren't scarey.  The premise itself is just silly.  All of Hitchcock's fancy camera work can't really hide that.  Hearing how Hitchcock was (allegedly) terrorizing Tipi Hedron behind the scenes; harassing her, (allegedly) threatening her and her daughter even; to the point where he did infact enclose her on the set with a bunch of wild birds at the ending; attempting to bring her to her knees after she continually rejected him; all of that is much scarier than this absurdist film.  As is Melanie Griffith's claim that during this period when she was a little girl; Hitchcock sent her a Barbie sized coffin; and when she opened it there was a doll laying down inside that looked exactly like her mother.  These allegation are pretty creepy.  And all of that, along with the stupid script, is enough to turn me off this movie.  The critical community be damned: this is still garbage!
This movie was so boring! What is going on!
The movie didn't age well- the 'special effects' are horrible, the plot isn't interesting and there's no culmination
I don't find it special, but is scary enough 7.8/10

The bird revolution is here in Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds. A very original horror film idea about how birds want to harm every human. While the film is considerably scary, the film does more than just rely on horror as it can get very dramatic and serious at some moments. The visuals are serviceable at times. The cinematography by Robert Burks was also quite nuanced especially during the film's climax where the humans barricade themselves inside the house and the electricity went out. Overall, The Birds is quite an interesting and original film that is slightly above average.

This movie has a good premise and while it may seem odd. The idea of birds killing people is pretty terrifying. However, this film falls short on the ending which seemed extremely rushed. Overall though it's a decent film.

This is one of my favorite Hitchcock films.  Everyone knows this film as the one where the birds attack and kill some unwitting people in a small northern California coastal village.  But it's more than that.  It's also a film about a complicated mother-son relationship, and a strong, (and well ahead of its time) look at relationships in general.  Even if you took the birds away, you'd still be left with a pretty interesting little film.  In fact, the genius of the film is that by the time you get to the bird attacks, Hitchcock had already created a strong narrative drama.  So when the birds do show up, you feel the impact they have on the characters that much more.
In short, this is not just another "when nature attacks" horror film.

Alfred Hitchcock's 1963 famous thriller focuses on a wealthy socialite pursuing a potential boyfriend when a series of sudden and unexplained violent bird attacks on the people of Bodega Bay, California, take place over the course of a few days. It is based upon the horror story by the British writer Daphne du Maurier, and even though the special effects are outdated, they convey the feeling of fear and danger, the film itself creates a great atmosphere of suspense and claustrophobia. With a bit of symbolism and an allegory for birds against humans for taking nature for granted, the film is enjoyable and a sample of the marvelous cinematic work of a genius which remains a classic 60 years later.

WOAH. tbh, i was not expecting the 5th entry in the LCU to be good at all  considering the quality of the last to films but holy shit this movie was actually pretty damn good. Turning Lyle into a bird this time around was a smart decision considering that he ate one in Dear Evan Hansen. My big problem though was the fact that they acknowledged ME TIME as canon. AMAZING plot twist at the end!

This is a typical Hitchock film in that its pretty tense and suspenseful at times, it keeps you guessing and isn't an all out horror film but perhaps more of a psychological thriller of sorts. I remember reading the story when I was in secondary school, so I had a rough idea of what to expect. The special effects are a bit tame (the bright red blood kept making me think of tomato ketchup - it didn't look like real blood at all I think but I'm maybe a bit of a nitpick?) but of course this is a film of its time, having been released in 1963. I thought it did quite well at making the viewer feel uneasy when faced with groups of birds stood congregating nearby, which is something I doubt anyone would normally bat an eyelid at. I imagine this was really quite a spooky and sinister perhaps even film of its time, although nowadays its hardly what I'd think of as a truly scary film (although one or two images I did find a little frightening) but I can understand why its well regarded and is a cult film. An interesting film by Hitchcock, based on a short story by Daphne DuMaurier, I'd recommend this.

A superior Hitchcock thriller. What's most worth savoring here is Hitch's time-tested method to his madness--he draws us in with absorbing characters and seemingly mundane drama, yet doesn't let you forget the creepy factor. But intricate plotting is a trademark for Hitch, and here it only helps to ratchet up the tension until the birds finally attack. Genuinely chilling scenes of vicious bird attacks help offset the slightly quaint "romance" going on here. What's probably most scary here is what is implied or isn't explained. Performances are solid, and the final shot will leave you with goosebumps. Creepy stuff

The concept behind "The Birds" evokes a deep-rooted sense of revulsion, greatly enhanced by the film's wise decision to abstain from providing tangible reasons behind the horrifying attacks. In appropriate fashion, Hitchcock also omits a music score, leaving us at the mercy of shrieks and squalls which quickly become heightened to truly claustrophobia-inducing proportions. Through such a calculating approach, Hitchcock offers us a thoroughly suspenseful experience against the backdrop of a story that evolves casually and even idyllically until the charming veneer is mercilessly shattered. The contrast is indeed quite striking, as we observe a story setting that might initially have been inspired by Hallmark card art eventually sling-shotting to the other extreme of near apocalyptic ruin. It may be noted that "The Birds" is one of the master's more expository works and might have benefited from slight editing, however I must admit that I've personally never felt bothered by the extra care and attention exercised in developing the central characters just that little bit more. Although never quite achieving reaching the heights of classic greatness of works such as "Psycho" and "Rear Window," "The Birds" is still a masterwork in suspense that richly succeeds in the development and execution of a concept that seems born of a half-repressed primordial fear.
One of the weaker Hitchcock films, but of course involving some wonderful filmmaking moments.

Although I've seen this film before, I not only barley remembered it, but what did remember wasn't much that I liked. Which I found odd considering this film's classic reputation. Watching The Birds again, I'm sad to say, my less than stellar memory of it wasn't far off.
Don't get me wrong, it's far from a bad! The acting is pretty good all around and I think it's fairly obvious (this being a Hitchcock film) that the tension and suspense in this movie is incredible.
But the pacing of the film is REALLY slow, the absurd nature of the plot often leans into unintentional comedy, and a lot of the effects really are very dated. 
I don't hate the film at all and I can see people who are afraid of birds being TERRIFIED of this film. I myself am not, so i just didn't get that much out of it.

As a massive Hitchcock fan, I saw The Birds, and it is a great film, very macabre, suspenseful and terrifying. Those bird fights alone are so well done, that I will admit I have never felt the same about birds again. The cinematography is brilliant, and the direction as you would expect from Hitchcock is superb. The screenplay is well crafted too, especially with "They're coming, they're coming".

The acting I thought was very good too, particularly from Rod Taylor and Susanne Pleshette, and Jessica Tandy and Tippi Hedren were excellent too. Even Hitch himself makes a "canine cameo". The atmosphere is terrific, enough to give you goosebumps. It is true, that there isn't much horror in the first forty minutes, but there is loads of suspense though, and the motive for the bird attacks never were explained. All in all, while not Hitch's best in my opinion, it is still a solid, perplexing and suspenseful horror/thriller, that may leave you terrified of birds. 9/10 Bethany Cox

'The Birds' is an interesting film but the plot sounds terrible if you think about it - 'Black killer birds group up to brutally attack citizens of the small town of Bodega Bay'. But Hitchcock really makes the film work. A thrilling and sometimes scary classic. Though the only problem is the ending, as it happens so sudden.

Another Hitchcock classic that left me a little underwhelmed. No doubting how freaky the bird attack scenes are but the production value is poor and I've no real idea what the point of it all was in the end. For suspense see dull.

One time, I was running and a bird attacked me because I got too close to the tree where its nest was located.  So I accepted the premise of the movie.  However, the movie was slow-moving with a lot of forced dialogue and mediocre acting.  As is annoyingly typical of horror movies, the writers have the characters do illogical and stupid things which put them in unnecessary danger.  While I don't like having everything spoon-fed to me, this movie left a lot of unanswered questions -- and worst of all ended abruptly as if they ran out of money and had to cut things short.   I will say that the special effects for the time period (1963) were pretty good, given that everything was done with film.  They would be laughable in a movie produced today, but they got the point across at that time.

It was ok. I wouldn't say that it was one of the greatest movies ever, but this is another movie where I feel like people should listen to others when they tell them things that they know about. The people in that restaurant were discussing what happened to them previously and what happened to some other people, and people weren't listening and they were getting killed.

The unmistakable chemistry between Melanie Daniels and Mitch Brenner commences in a San Francisco pet store and develops into an instinctive romance when she follows him to his family farm in Bodega Bay to deliver to him the gift of lovebirds. The butterflies soon come to a screeching halt, though, when their sparsely populated Californian village is attacked by a sea of maniacal birds!

"‘The Birds' Is An Extremely Innovative Thriller Film. Hitchcock's Mastery Of Suspense, Avant-Garde Cinematography, Practical Visual Effects, Haunting Shots, And Clever Sound Design All Play Their Part In What Makes This 1963 Romantic Horror-Mystery Noteworthy. 

The Film Barely Has A Musical Score Which Made Those Drawn Out Silences Suspenseful. And Electrifying.

However, My Favorite Aspect Of The Film Is The Dialogue. It's Casual And Sophisticated, But Nearly Every Line Serves As Some Sort Of Foreshadowing, Proving Evan Hunter's Script To Be A Skillfully Written One. 

The Brilliant Thespians, Notably Tippi Hedren And Jessica Tandy, Kept Me Glued To The Screen And Enthralled With Their Horrifying Quandary. 

I Recommend You Give This ‘Terrifying Motion Picture' A Nighttime Viewing... And Remember, The Next Scream You Hear May Be Your Own." 82%!
For the technology they had available at the time, fantastic. Lots of layers here to digest.

If not quite the master's greatest it has many iconic sequences and sticks in the mind. The escape from the school is my favourite sequence. It of course has gained relevance over time with the idea that nature might turn against us and with its ambiguous ending - will the birds attack again? or is it over? Often copied. The score is also superb. However, the acting is not as good as his greatest efforts nor is the plotting and cohesion - understandable as this is from a short story and there is no real development, that is not the point. None of this detracts from the iconic status of the film or its continued impact.

I have been watching Alfred Hitchcock's movie nowadays. His movies are so different and fun to watch. He made movies which were ahead of it's time including this one.

The story shown in the movie had a lot of potential but the ending in which there was no reasoning was a let down. Also, the story felt incomplete. They could have made a proper story with 2 hour runtime but they focused too much on story build-up only. The movie was enjoyable. The direction and performances by the actors were good. There is thrill and drama which keeps this movie on track.

Overall, it is a good horror thriller drama which will keep you bounded till the end but the climax portion may disappoint you.

Still a classic. Amazing special effects even now, let alone back than. Good acting. I know allot of people complain about not knowing why the birds go bunkers, I like that fact we don't know. Just proves that it could happen and our feathered friends, by most accounts are descendants of the dinosaurs, could just one day get some payback.

This has got to be one of the dumbest movies I've ever watched. Birds killing people is too absurd even for the 60s. Not to mention the terrible effects and the laughable acting. I guess watching other Alfred Hitchcock movies just because I liked Psycho is a mistake.
When we talk about slow-burn horror thrillers, we are talking about "The Birds".  Brilliant. Flawless. And not even Hitchcock's best.

I can appreciate how much of the discomfort and horror from this nearly 60-year-old film still comes through, and I appreciate the way the birds seem to be some sort of commentary on the self-indulgent prankster lifestyle of Melanie. The scene in the bar, followed by the massive bird attack, is really great material. So is the claustrophobic, anxious sequence in the boarded-up home. But for whatever reason, the characters and the thematic content of this Hitchcock work didn't quite deliver on the same level his other work does.
I always forget how bone-chilling it truly is until I experience it again. Especially that final shot.
A movie that is a metaphor for how Hitchcock perceived strong women (watch it and see if you agree). Scavenger birds attack a small fishing village for seemingly no reason, i.e., Birds are scary.
Clueless people taking shelter in balsa wood buildings. I don't think the movie premise was explored as well as it could have been.
How can people be so afraid of birds, is beyond me, this is Alfred Hitchcock at his worst!
Birds attacking people unbeknownst the reason why with Rod Taylor and Tipi Heydren as the stars.
One of the most boring horror movies of all time.
Definitely one of my most favourite classic films. Definitely Alfred Hitchcock's best work. Great acting and story.

Birds Together Strong

The last of the Alfred Hitchcock's films that I will watch for now. Adapted from the work of Daphne du Maurier who wrote one of my favorite novels Rebecca, the plot was simply about the mysterious attacks from the birds.

The first half of the movie was purely setting up the characters while hinting at the looming upcoming attacks from the birds. Honestly I had no idea how spending so much time on developing the characters related to the story of the birds. For me, this part was definitely the weakest because it was unnecessarily long.

The movie got better when the birds started their large-scale attacks. Honestly I think that with better technology, the attacks would have more enjoyment and be scarier. Of course, this is not the movie's fault, but it still affected the experience. However, most of the suspense came from before the attacks, where characters had to be careful moving around the gathering birds. This part was good, although I think it can be better. 

Overall, it's not as good as Vertigo or Rear Window. 7/10
This is such a classic that you MUST see it!  Great special effects.

In Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds, the initial premise of a habitual prankster delivering a pair of lovebirds to a handsome stranger who she feels slighted her is a bit thin and highly improbable, but once the Hitchcock twist comes and it goes from a creepy blossoming romance story to a full out horror show, things become interesting.  Some of the bird scenes are spectacular, including the final shot, while others are wildly outdated (the children running from the school while under attack) and are more likely to provoke laughs than chills.  Regardless, once the action kicks in, The Birds is a wildly entertaining spin on the animals run amok genre of horror.
Ages 13+ only; yet so worth it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Hitchcock revisits the human trope of complacency that he did to such great effect in Shadow of a Doubt. Suspenseful thrill ride that starts out a bit screwball comedy style only to get much darker. Includes an Oscar worthy performance by Jessica Tandy. Recommended.
I liked the film more at the end honestly, because in the starting bit it was a bit boring, but the developing of the story was awesome.
Awesome movie the birds themselves could probably make someone terrified of them and it has some good effects
While most people might complain about the behind the scenes trouble and no score but it's a terrifying and a masterfully directed disaster thriller from the master of suspense
The Birds is definitely a animal gone berserk horror film with really amazing special effects and it's still a horror masterpiece film.
Due to the effects not having ageed well, The Birds produces more laughs than dread and horror

Watching The Birds almost 60 years after its release and I still marvel and the filmmaking genius of Alfred Hitchcock. Every mass bird attack is directed in an iconic manner that other moviemakers have copied in some form. Tippi Hedren, who reportedly was the victim of unwanted sexual advances by Hitchcock, provides a stunning and courageous performance

An American classic. So much to love about this film: Tippi Hedren is awesome, and the chemistry between the two leads (Hedren and Rod Taylor) is terrific. Even better are the political and social undertones, most importantly the lesson that we should always be willing to accept things that challenge established knowledge when they present themselves.

It's such a great film and lesson bout respecting nature. The main characters are such a mystery that the whole time you wanna throw the birds in the background and figure out if the two "lovebirds" actually have dark plans for each other. We are trained not to trust humans like this while history tells us we can trust birds. Eventually the birds take center stage, not as a villain but as a protestor to the audience that it will not be used as a plot device. Two alpha manipulators are forced to humble themselves and it's a great lesson.

The Birds contained more apparent symbolism for me than any of Hitchcock's other films I have seen up to this point. I especially appreciated the more naturally ambiguous ending and thought the lack of a concrete explanation helps sustain the feeling of uneasiness or dread long after the films conclusion. 7.5/10

A so-called horror film that lacks the kind of atmosphere, direction, music, thrills or chills that a proper horror film requires. Hedren's performance seems to be the sole life of Hitchcock's version of a "creature feature".
The special effects, the story, the suspense - they all work, even decades later, even after viewing for the 3rd or 4th time. Amazing film, fascinating to watch and to think about.

Despite the female characters in this film all being somewhat fragile to say the least, I do enjoy this film.  It scared me a lot as a child.  It is also one of the few "horror" movies I can watch with my spouse who hates horror movies.
If you want to see how props as coy as little birds can create tension and terror, watch  maestro in Hitchcock lead you there.
Alfred Hitchcock strikes again with a film that shows that build-up is the true key to suspense and shows off some effects that were as innovative as they were effective.
Bad Alfred Hitchcock movie.
10% Overrated. Directing was good, but the acting & storyline were absolutely terrible.
I just can't take it seriously. It seems more like a comedy.
Although not frightening by today's standards, I still find it to be a captivating watch.

The Birds inhabits a strange and unique place in film history. Despite falling well short of the high water mark set by Hitchcock in some of his more character-driven films, The Birds is one of the films that is most clearly embedded in the popular consciousness when his name is brought up. The story is almost painfully silly and the characters hollow, but single shots are some of the most suspenseful and well-designed in horror film history. Simple, unadorned takes of groups of birds gradually accumulating without any musical accompaniment, only the occasional shrill call, intimidate far more than they would have if left to a lesser director (the gathering outside the schoolhouse is positively fantastic). The actual attacks incorporate such woefully outdated visual effects, whether through merging shots or less than believable animatronics. Whenever the threat of the birds is palpable, but the birds themselves are unseen, the film is often great, allowing the fears of the audience to fill in the vague threats established by circumstance. Some of the film is poorly conceived to the point of being comical, such as the gas station explosion and the quick reaction cuts on display. For some reason, much of the later film seems to evoke memories of Battleship Potempkin, particularly the Odessa Steps sequence with respect to the children fleeing the schoolhouse (which was the plan why?), and close, frontal shots of characters in emotionally compromised states. Taken together, The Birds feels less like a complete horror classic than a grab bag of tricks prepared by a capable, but unfocused, production team. (3.5/5)

Of all of Hitchcock's films, this is my least favorite. I like birds. The Cardinals are my favorite baseball team; the Crows and Magpies are my favorite Aussie Rules football teams. Why does he have to pick on birds? And why, especially, did he have to be such a petulant SOB with women?

Demonstrating Hitchcock's mastery at building suspense rather than delivering all-out thrills, The Birds has maybe not held up as well as some of the director's other works, in part to due to special effects limitations. Some shots are kept noticeably short and it's easy to see why. A lot of blatantly obvious green screening is used, and some shots of birds attacking are used multiple times. But what makes the film work is its use of identifiable characters and tangible threats. Birds are something that we see everyday and give little thought to, so its frightening to imagine what those creatures would do if they turned hostile, and how powerless we would be to fight them off. The film does drag in places, and much like the ending of Psycho, some conversations do go on for far too long. But Hitchcock knew what he was doing, and what he could use to scare the audience, going as far as to blare bird noises from a speaker following the UK premier. For me it didn't have the same impact or suspense as something like Psycho or Rear Window, but it still works well because of how effectively the threat is portrayed, and how well fleshed out the characters become. It might not be Hitch's best, but it's certainly one of his most iconic.

Filmed in Hitchcock's signature style of camerawork, and another build-up to the suspense, the Birds shows how villains can be made out of anything. A more violent movie from the early 60s, and with a good supporting performance from Suzanne Pleshette, the Birds fails horribly in one thing: making a good ending. It just ends; without logic, reason, or an explanation. But if you look past that, it is a chilling, suspenseful triumph that any Hitchcock fan will be hooting for.

The title pretty much says it all in this distinctly Hitchcockian mix of petty social gamesmanship and an abrupt, all-encompassing existential threat. That being the killer birds, obviously, which dive in from nowhere to ruthlessly head-hunt the poor denizens of a sleepy marine village in northern California.

It sounds like an odd mix, but it in practice... well, okay, it is an odd mix. The film's sudden about-face, from a slow moving game of flirty pranks to a breakneck avian assault, is disruptive and awkward, its pace a whiplashed tug-of-war between monotonous waits and unannounced bursts of frenzy. I like the metaphorical idea behind it, a pontification on natural catastrophes and how quickly they lead polite society to break down, but didn't enjoy much of the experience itself.

In many ways, it's a precursor to the glut of disaster movies that flooded cinemas in the following decade: one central menace, easy enough to boil down to a single word, which sends everybody scurrying in a desperate, improvised bid for survival. The effects are glaringly bad, too, bad enough to, more than once, completely pull me out of the moment with a snicker or a snort. The last big scare scene, however, is all sound and tension, and works so much better for its restraint and subtlety, putting the more garish, visceral preceding shots to shame by leaning on a few wild-eyed close-ups. I can see what Hitchcock was shooting for, but I don't think he got there.

Hitchcock spends quite a while introducing us to the characters and making us care for them, while at the same time, meticulously revealing the horror about to rear its ugly head. That is what makes Hitchcock such a legend, he knows how to scare us. With excellent film-making and great performances all around, The Birds is a horror masterpiece that is surprisingly still terrifying.

A Haunting Fairytale.
Fairytales, even those for kids, are seldom serene and innocent. Think of Little Red Riding Hood, Cinderella, Hansel and Gretel, full of mysterious and haunting characters imbued with evil.

The Birds, released three years after Psycho, a gap relatively long for Hitchcock but explained also by the technical challenges of the production, contains all the trademarks typical of both his cinema style and the fairytales.
The blond and beautiful leading lady, much stronger and determined than the appearances suggest, the light initial tone, almost a comedy with the witty bickering of the main characters, the unmissable Hitch's cameo, the long and winding coastal road, the ingenious quotes of his previous movies, here The 39 steps and To Catch a Thief amongst others, are intertwined with the inexplicable evil and the helplessness of the darkest fairytales' personas.

But The Birds, loosely based on a short story published in 1952 by Daphne du Maurier, an author that the English master had already used as a source for Rebecca and Jamaica Inn, is also deeply experimental and has a philosophical sophistication unrivalled by any of Hitchcock's movies.
Since the opening credits, evoking the optical expressionist illusions of Escher's birds, the film is imbued with a haunting introspection that is ultimately only enhanced by the lively beginning of the movie, when Mitch, an anonymous Rod Taylor, meets and squabbles with Melanie, Tippi Hedren on her cinema debut. 
The director's choice of giving up a musical soundtrack, with the only music briefly played by Melanie on the piano and the nursery rhyme sang by the school children, skipping the end credits and a real, defined ending, the sophisticated special effects engineered for the birds' attacks, that all in all have well survived time and digitalisation, the dilution of time and pace challenging and almost mocking the viewer, like in the emblematic scene of the crows perched on the jungle gym, the unpredictable and random behaviour of the birds, the roles' reverse, with the humans forced by attacks and fear to look for protection into the cages, either houses, cars, bars, phone boots, coinciding with the mental cages built by the terror generated by the distortion of the natural order that everybody is used to and expects, make The Birds an overwhelming complex movie to watch and understand, difficult to define, in between horrors and thrillers and that in fact was not very much appreciated by both the critics and the public when released.
Only recently the first Hitchcock movie produced and distributed by Universal has been heralded as one of his bests and most likely his last masterpiece, as well as a trailblazer on the analyses of the sickness and inner demons of the human psyche.

The Birds is a movie that leaves a long-lasting impression in the discerning viewer, notwithstanding the mediocrity of the actors, with the exceptions on an intense Jessica Tandy as Mitch's mother and a convincing Suzanne Pleshette as Annie, the sacrificial lamb of both Mitch and the birds.
Regrettably, the few films Alfred Hitchcock directed after The Birds, however well-crafted and a pleasure to watch, will not add anything to the film body of one of the most important filmmakers of the XX Century.
A perfect showcase of the effectiveness of building tension and haunting atmosphere, an also shows unlikely but iconic horror figures.

The Birds (1963) is not only the first Hitchcock film I ever saw as a child, but it remains one of my very favorites. Its title being a double entendre for the physical animals attacking people as well as the British slang term for women. As I just now realize that The Birds is really a drama and romance movie all about one suave man named Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor) and his relationship between all the women in his life. It's a fascinating story about trust, love, survival, kindness, and abandonment from the mind of writer Daphne du Maurier.

The real star of The Birds is the lovely Tippi Hedren in her debut feature film. Hedren portrays a confident young woman named Melanie Daniels, whose rich lifestyle leads her to new perils. Hedren is not only beautiful in her green suit, fur coat, done up blonde hair, and sweet voice, but she also acts very well. She carries the film with her easy charm and playful demeanor. You just want to know more about her. Hedren should have gotten more roles after The Birds, but unfortunately Hitchcock only cast her in Marnie. She is really wonderful in The Birds.

Another excellent performance comes from the mesmerizing Suzanne Pleshette as Annie Hayworth. She exudes a mysterious air and enchanting manner in The Birds. I like how her character's past is slowly revealed as The Birds goes on all helped by Pleshette's uneasy warmth. She kills it in The Birds.

Lastly, Jessica Tandy ties the story together as the mother afraid of abandonment with her hysterical outbursts and terrified screams. Tandy gives one of the most captivating performances of her illustrious career.

Overall, Hitchcock really has something here with The Birds. From long creeping panning shots to build up suspense to sudden cuts or zooms in on the horror, Hitchcock will scare or unnerve you at some point while watching The Birds. I still cannot figure out how he got so many birds to act so still or violent to make the movie. Clearly, he utilizes green screens, early CGI, puppets, and edits to make most of the birds look great on camera. But there are still times I cannot understand how The Birds still looks real.
A masterpiece by master director Hitchcock.

The Birds finds Hitchcock at his very best building up the tension and creating suspense. The way the minor details are revealed in this movie is enough to make you glued to the screen throughout the whole movie, but I already know that Hitchcock is the best in doing this.
What I didn't know before watching this movie is that The Master of Suspense is also a Master of Symbolism!

Many people consider The Birds as one of Hitchcock most modest films, even some of his fans. I can see why, and it's simply because the movie seems that it left a lot of very important questions unanswered. I said it seems because it really did answer these questions symbolically.

I won't spoil anything for those who haven't seen this gem yet, but I'll just point that the key to all these questions is a very important character and everything related to it.

Just try to think which character the movie gave it a lot of exposition, and you'll easily understand the whole movie. And there is where I've an issue with The Birds. I think it gives a lot of explanations to this character that we don't necessarily need to because the movie expose some details what have already been revealed before. That being said, all characters are well-grounded, compelling, interesting, and necessary to the plot.

All the performances were excellent, specially from Tippi Hedren who played the movie's protagonist. She is a wonderful actress, and her performance in this movie is nothing short of endearing. She is as charming as Audrey Hepburn!

Some few decisions the characters made, may be one or two, are not so subtle, but the execution of the results to these decisions is what annoyed me a little bit. The characters seemed forced to fall into the trap.

Although there is some blood and gore in this movie, Alfred Hitchcock proves again that what the scenes imply can be way more brutal than what they show. The scenes when the titular creatures attack are very painful to watch. Adding insult to injury, the birds acquire a metaphorical complexity that is as distressing as their beaks!

Overall, The Birds is a very underrated Hitchcock film that doesn't lack any of Hitchcock's unparalleled brilliance. Also it would make a great companion to Hitchcock's most famous work, Psycho!

I just watched this movie last night at the historic Los Angeles Theater for a special event and despite the somewhat silly concept (there are some comedic moments in the film so I'm pretty sure Hitchcock was aware of this), it's another really good film which helps to further bolster Hitchcock's legendary status. There are legitimate moments of suspense and moments that creep up on you until it's too late. Some of the 60s effects are a bit dated and it can get a little slow sometimes, but it's still a fine piece of filmmaking with great build up and terrific performances.

Unsurprisingly, it works best when the birds are attacking, providing for some scary and tense scenes with a fantastic sound design that really does make all the difference. The acting is good too, with Tippi Hedren stealing the show. That being said, the build-up is just too long (it's almost an hour before anything particularly unusual happens) and it's not nearly as terrifying or well-written (some of the decisions the characters make are particularly stupid, to say the least) as its reputation would suggest. In anyone else's hands this could have been a disaster, but with good ol' Hitch at the helm, ratcheting up the tension and suspense, it becomes a far better film than it should be. Certainly not his best, but iconic, nonetheless.

Well, The Birds certainly takes a turn, doesn't it? For what seems like almost an hour this movie barely even hints at what it will become. It feels like a simple relationship drama as we see these two characters meet and grow closer while dealing with all the family and friends that surround them. We wander through a series of scenes that introduce us to all our characters, as they run around from one place to the next. All of this is vital information that makes the rest of the film work. We care about the characters because we got to know them early in the film, and we know where they are headed at any given time because we already are aware of the layout of the town.

When the tone shifts, it turns on a dime and truly becomes a horror film. This is where we totally get to experience the amazing talents of Hitchcock. There are so many scenes where the tension builds brilliantly, and that's what makes for a film that is genuinely scary. We can feel the dread along with the people in the film, and even when they don't see it coming, we do. There were a couple of those classic horror movie moments where you get annoyed with the characters for doing something stupid and risky, but it added to the scares so it's hard to complain. Hitchcock also has a knack for framing shots just right, and he knows how to use sound (or leave it out) to heighten the mood.

I've often heard people say that Hitchcock struggles with ending movies, so it seems his solution with The Birds was simply not to end it at all. This movie stops so abruptly that I thought the blu-ray had somehow skipped a final scene. I don't need to have the reason for the bird attacks explained, it's alright that we're left to guess. I don't even need for the movie to tell me what happens next for our characters. But I need to feel like the movie genuinely concluded. Even if it's just "The End" on the screen or something. This wasn't enough to ruin The Birds for me, but it did leave me on a sour note. Otherwise this was a very well-crafted movie with a great cast and some of Hitchcock's best scares ever.

The Birds is one of Alfred Hitchcock's most iconic films, along with Psycho and North by Northwest. The film has good acting from both Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor. The film is very well directed by Hitchcock as there is a lot of build up which may feel slow but is necessary to make us care about the characters. Once the birds attack the film is very thrilling and gets more and more tense until you get to the end. All of the bird attack scenes are very tense and get quite violent which is surprising considering this film was made in the 60's when censorship was a lot stricter. The film is well written and edited and isn't really boring although it does move at a slow pace. There are lots of iconic and thrilling moments such as the iconic phone booth scene and the school scene. The school scene is a very tense and very well set up scene that is brilliantly directed by the brilliant Hitchcock and has a great pay off. The scene where Tippi is attacked in the attic is quite possibly the most disturbing and tense moments. Hitchcock wanted this scene to feel like a rape and he really captured the intensity and horror perfectly. The bird attack is also well set up as we get brief little hints there is something wrong with the birds before they attack so when they actually do attack it's been well set up and doesn't come out of nowhere. While this is a very good film it is quite dated. For one the birds are obviously super imposed and while some shots of them attacking looks real, most of it looks rather fake which is understandable as this film is nearly 50 years old. Also while the set up is necessary I do feel it goes on for too long and does get a little tedious. Also the lack of music I feel at points is very noticeable like when the mother character finds this dead body it does feel a little odd with no music. However the birds is a really good if not great film. I highly recommend it to any fan of films or in particular fans of Hitchcock. After having surprised and shocked audiences with Psycho, Alfred Hitchcock followed it up with another horror film, The Birds, which is more straightforward and generic than the rest of his films, but he still did experiment quite a bit with some elements here. There are no surprises or unexpected twists in The Birds and it pretty much plays out as a standard thriller slowly building the suspense by introducing us to the characters so we can identify with them. He didn't use psychological suspense either like he did in so many of his films, he just let the narrative unfold gradually. This may sound like a standard horror film, but what Hitchcock experiments with here is the lack of a musical score to accompany the film. Most thrillers rely on eerie scores to help set the mood, and we know Hitchcock included them often such as in films like Vertigo and Psycho, but here rather than introducing music he uses the sound of birds to scare audiences. Many people complain that the effects are outdated, but it didn't bother me at all, I thought they were really well done and I felt the tension during some of these scenes that have become classic by now (such as the scene where Tippi Hedren's character is trapped inside a phone booth as the birds are attacking the town, and the climatic scene where the birds are surrounding Rod Taylor's home). Those were memorable scenes full of tension, but I did have some issues with the pacing of the story. 

Hitchcock made sure we cared for the characters and during the first hour of the film he spends time building a possible romantic relationship between Rod Taylor and Tippi Hedren. This is where I wished the main characters were played by more charismatic actors such as James Stewart and Kim Novak where the chemistry between them would seem stronger, and that would have engaged me more with a story I kind of felt was silly otherwise. The premise is kind of out there since I really never believed the threat of the birds nor felt their presence haunting, but Hitchcock still managed to build in a few scares despite it all. The bay near San Francisco where this film mostly takes place was a perfect setting and I actually enjoyed the fact that it took place in an enclosed space like this. It sort of made the audience believe these characters were enclosed and surrounded by the birds. Hitchcock can build suspense out of nearly anything and despite my disbelief of the birds being a real threat there were times I did feel that tension. The way in which he exchanges shots from one scene to the next like he did in the phone booth with exterior shots exchanged with interior ones really helps build the suspense and create a tense atmosphere. The Birds may not have much psychological depth, but it plays out quite well as a generic disaster film and slowly builds its way up to a rather interesting climatic scene (I mean switch the birds for zombies and you realize where George A. Romero may have got his ideas for Night of the Living Dead). The Birds isn't amongst my favorite Hitchcock films, but I still had a fun time with it.

Yes, in a way Hitchcock's "The Birds" isn't greatly structured in its plot, but it does not seem as if that was Hitchcock's intention for this movie. One of Hitchcock's greatest achievements in this movie and, in fact all time is that he was able to depict the common bird, seen by the average person on a day to day basis as a harmful and pesty animal as a jaw-droppingly fearful subject. Unlike, "Psycho" or "Vertigo", "the Birds" wasn't building up to a suspenseful and unpredictable conclusion, it was simply changing the philosophy of the nature of birds. It sounds so ridiculous, that Hitchcock could make such a harmful animal the central and commanding fear of his movie, but he was able to pull it off in such great fashion that it was almost satirical.

The Birds is a successful suspense-filled movie due to a number of things. Firstly, the parts are well played. Tippi Hedren isn't just your typical "blonde haired romantic victim" but actually builds characters as she moves through the well written narrative. Rod Taylor also creates a character who grows on you as the film goes on. The script works well and does not rush things. The advantage of this type of story is the unpredictable conclusion to the problem. Without going into the extremes of the military, explosions and so on, how exactly do you save a small town being over run with millions of birds? It's not a scenario which happens, thus making you actually wonder to yourself how they will overcome it. The ending may not please some people, but I feel it is the best way to end a story like this.
The biggest worry I had going into an early 60's film about killer birds is how effective they would actually look on screen. Surprisingly, the Birds pull it off extremely well and shows why it was nominated at the Oscars for Visual Effects. Whilst there is the odd shot of a bad looking bird here and there, the majority of shots are pulled off really well. Birds are unpredictable creatures so I was especially amazed at the scene involving a good hundred crows waiting patiently on a climbing frame. 
I can understand why a modern audience may find it dated but if you going into it with an open mind and a reminder of the year it was made in, then you will surely come to enjoy the best Hitchcock can provide.

I joke, but this was Alfred Hitchcock's last huge hit, insinuating that he had time to make huge hits prior, and that would be great if this film was by any means "soaring" (Ha-ha-ha-caw!), being an unreasonably two hours reasonably well-spent, but not especially smoothly.

The film is plenty well-developed, with its characters, and its settings, and even its themes, but not with, of all things, it's conflict, for although I can understand the ambiguity behind the birds' mania, and although they attempt explanations way late into the body of the film, it's hard to get all that invested in a conflict so underdeveloped. Well, the conflict at least seems underdeveloped, compared to the other aspects of this narrative, whose build-up segment runs for way, way too long, until it begins to feel aimless, just as the relatively tighter body gets to be draggy itself. Running two hours in length, the film is simply too long, and that's perhaps my biggest problem with it, as the film is all too often all too meandering to be all that engaging, and would be more compelling during its lulls in conflict if it was more genuine. The script is decent, but it holds problems extending beyond the uneven pacing, particularly within its dramatics, as the personal character conflicts feel a touch too Hollywood in their being histrionic, and working to manufacture some depth to a story of limited weight. Alas, screenwriter Evan Hunter can't quite overshadow the limitations in depth within this Hollywood thriller, which are all but overpowered by inspiration to storytelling, sure, but don't do a whole lot at all, much less anything all that uniquely. The film wasn't especially refreshing even for its time, no matter, how much it tried, at least at times, when it wasn't getting too lazy, if not overblown with its exposition and conflicts to truly reward. The film is kind of underwhelming, but it's not as underwhelming as I feared it might be, being bland in more than a few areas, but effective enough in others to impress just fine, particularly on a technical level.

The bird effects have, of course, become rather dated over the years, even with often their being presented in a frantic fashion that is ostensibly intended to give you only so much time to see the seams, yet they hold up just fine, and when their sheer business go accompanied by unique and disturbing sound effects, a sense of pandemonium is sold, and augmented by the staging of the action sequence. As you can imagine, it's a long while before tensions begin to rise, but when they do, the technical value, alone, however dated, thrills, viscerally and as a reinforcement of a sense of consequence to substance. As for the substance, I won't so much so that it's lacking, as much as I would say that it is, in fact, kind of overblown, being dragged out and histrionic, as well as formulaic, although that isn't to say that there isn't still something limited to the weight of this drama, and yet, with that said, the story concept, even for the time, is not as silly as it could have been, holding a chillingly believable primary conflict, behind interesting themes regarding natural tragedies, and even the depths of humanity in times of terror. The more human side of the film is really sold by the performances, which aren't graced with all that much material, but surprisingly stand out when the plot begin to thicken, with most everyone nailing a sense of sheer emotional distraught and human anguish that, when backed by layered chemistry, sell the many conflicts seen in a terrorized community with a convincing intensity that may have been beyond the time, at least in Hollywood affairs. Again, the dramatics get a little too Hollywood histrionic, but in plenty of areas, this film was gutsy enough to transcend traditional, watered down Hollywoodisms, and such audacity still rings true today in its graphic emphasis on disaster and human flaws, sold by the solid performances, both on the screen and off. What truly defines the effectiveness of this film is, of course, Alfred Hitchcock, whose directorial skills are limited by a questionable script, but are inspired enough to play an instrumental role in getting the film as far as it goes, playing up quietness just right to prevent dullness and establish genuine suspense, while placing a harsh attention to violence and claustrophobia in order to really drive the intensity that in turn drives this thriller, at least at times. The film takes much too long to pick up, and it ultimately fails to reward on the whole, but there are plenty of moments that really are more audacious and effective than one might fear, and in between them is a film that entertains enough to join the thrilling highlights in establishing a very decent, if a touch overblown Hollywood thriller.

When the flock has cleared the air, little development to the ultimate conflict and too much development to an overdrawn build-up segment, with the help of some Hollywood melodrama, conventions and narrative thinness, wear the film down until it slips into underwhelmingness, but not so deeply that strong effects and action, interesting thematic depth, strong acting and effective direction aren't able to drive Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds" close enough to a rewarding point to intrigue adequately as a flawed, but classic portrait on extreme natural disaster.
